revision.text:
[[File:Xavier Hommaire de Hell (3).jpg|thumb|150px|Xavier Hommaire de Hell, drawing by [[Jules Laurens]]]]
'''Ignace Xavier Morand Hommaire de Hell''', often known as '''Xavier Hommaire de Hell''', (24 November 1812 in [[Altkirch]] – 29 August 1848 in [[Isfahan]]) was a French geographer, engineer and traveller who carried out research in [[Turkey]], southern Russia and [[Iran|Persia]].
==Biography==
After attending school in Altkirch and [[Dijon]], Hommaire graduated as an engineer at the [[École Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Saint-Étienne|École des Mines]] in [[Saint-Étienne]] in 1833. There he met Adèle Hériot whom he married in 1834. In October 1835, he went Turkey where he coordinated the construction of a [[suspension bridge]] in [[Istanbul|Constantinople]] and a lighthouse on the [[Black Sea]] coast. In 1838, he arrived in southern Russia where he performed [[ethnography|ethnographical]] research and geographical surveys. After he discovered coal resources along the [[Dnieper River]], [[Nicholas I of Russia|Czar Nicholas I]] awarded him the [[Order of St. Vladimir|St Vladimir Cross]]. In 1842, while working on mining and road-building projects in [[Moldavia]], he fell ill and returned to France. The following year he became a member of the ''[[Société de Géographie]]'' and the ''[[Société géologique de France|Société géologique]]'' and published a number of scientific papers. In 1844 the Société de Géographie awarded him their [[Gold Medal of the Société de Géographie|Gold Medal]] .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socgeo.org/grande-medaille-dor-des-explorations-et-voyages-de-decouverte/| title=GRANDE MÉDAILLE D’OR DES EXPLORATIONS ET VOYAGES DE DÉCOUVERTE (in French)|publisher=Société de géographie|accessdate=1 December 2014}}</ref>
With the help of his wife, he embarked on ''Les steppes de la mer Caspienne'' (1844–1847) and in 1845 was awarded the [[Legion of Honour]].<ref name=iranica>[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/hommaire-de-hell Jacqueline Calmard-Compas, "Hommaire de Hell, Ignace Xavier Morand"], ''Encyclopaedia Iranica''. Retrieved 29 April 2012.</ref>
After receiving a grant of 3,000 francs per year from the Ministry of Commerce and Agriculture, he left with his wife and the painter [[Jules Laurens]] on an extended journey to the Orient. In Turkey, he wrote reports on trade in the [[Bosporous]] and the Black Sea before proceeding to Persia. As he expected the journey to be difficult, he sent his wife back to France, travelling only with Laurens. In June 1847, they sailed to [[Trabzon]], entering Persia through [[Diyarbakir]] and [[Lake Van]] that November. In February 1848, he finally arrived in [[Tehran]] after suffering from cholera and [[ophthalmia]] on the way. With the help of the French ambassador, he met [[Mohammad Shah Qajar]] who entrusted him with studying the feasibility of a canal bringing water from the [[Shahrood (River)|River Shahrood]] to the [[Savojbolagh County|Savojbolagh plain]]. Hommaire left for [[Mazandaran Province|Mazandaran]] in May 1848 where he carried out surveys including a study of the [[Jameh Mosque of Varamin|Mosque of Varamin]]. He returned to Tehran to complete his research notes and then travelled to [[Isfahan]]. He arrived there seriously ill and died two weeks later on 29 August 1848. Laurens sent his notes back to his wife in Paris who completed a full account of his travels (1856–1860) subsidized by the French authorities.<ref name=iranica/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *''Atlas historique et scientifique'', Paris, 1859; = Tome IV of Voyage en Turquie et en Perse exécuté par ordre du gouvernement français pendant les années 1846, 1847 et 1848 par Xavier Hommaire de Hell, Paris, 1856-59. *J. Laurens, ''Nazar-endaz, Episode d’un voyage en Perse'', Revue orientale et algérienne, 1853–54, pp. 342–51; repr. in J. Laurens, ''La légende des ateliers'', Paris, 1901. *Xavier Hommaire de Hell, ''Les steppes de la mer caspienne, la Crimée et la Russie méridionale'', Paris, 3 Vols., 1844-47. *Xavier Hommaire de Hell, ''Voyage en Turquie et en Perse, executé par ordre du gouvernement français pendant les années 1846, 1847, et 1848'', compiled by Jules Laurens, Paris 1856-60.
==External links== {{commons category|Jules Laurens}} * {{Gutenberg author | id=Hell,+Xavier+Hommaire+de }} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Xavier Hommaire de Hell}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hommaire de Hell, Xavier}} [[Category:French geographers]] [[Category:French engineers]] [[Category:1812 births]] [[Category:1848 deaths]] [[Category:People from Altkirch]] [[Category:Légion d'honneur recipients]] [[Category:Members of the French Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Burials in Iran]] [[Category:Human geographers]]
